bibl.title: Letter from John P. Felt to Frederick F. Russell, April 14, 1923

div1.p: Felt reports on yellow fever at Saltpond, Gold Coast.

div1.head: Letter from John P. Felt to Frederick F. Russell, April 14, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
I. H. B.
Africa
JOHN P. FELT
126 State Street
Boston 2. April 14, 1923
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York City.
Attention of F. F. Russell, M.D.
Dear Sirs:
div1.p:
I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 13th, enclosing copy
of letter dated March 17th, received from the senior medical officer of the
Gold Coast Harbours, together with copies of correspondence pertaining to the
Serum and Vaccine supplied my correspondents at Saltpond, Gold Coast, West
Africa. Thank you for the information.

Under date of March 27th my correspondents, the Compagnie Francaise
de l'Afrique Occidentale, wrote from their head office at Marseille, France,
as follows:-
“We duly received your letter of the 16th of March.

Our factory at Accra has advised us, under date of February 20th,
1923, that Dr. Ker of the Takoradi Works went to Saltpond to come to an under-
standing with the physician of that place. It has been agreed that, should
another case declare itself, Dr. Ker would send immediately from Sekondi an
automobile with serum. (In order to retain its efficiency it appears that this
serum must be kept at low temperature, and Saltpond has no ice.)

Our factory at Saltpond advised on the 15th of March that new cases of
yellow fever have been ascertained amongst the natives, which has called for the
maintenance of the quarantine. Since the 31st of January no death of Europeans
have taken place as far as we know.

At Cape Coast-Castle a European died of yellow fever on the 27th of
February, 1923, but as it was an isolated case the city was not quarantined.

We will be pleased to report, through you, to the Rockefeller Founda-
tion all information that we obtain concerning the Yellow Fever in West Africa.”

On receipt of addition information from my correspondents will write
you promptly.
